Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, probably an amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of part of body and arms of charioteer standing to right (long chiton in added white with incised belt and vertical fold lines); chariot shown in frontal view (part of front railing and trace of box preserved); male figure stepping into chariot shown in frontal view (frontal greave on right leg; garment with broad stripes in black and added red, with faded white dot rosettes on black bands; bottom edge decorated with zigzag between narrow bands, each with row of white dots); at right, part of chest and upper foreleg of horse that charioteer holds; behind the charioteer, part of right chariot wheel (red on rim); at far left, part of undetermined figure.
Curator's comments: Venit cites as a parallel regarding the frontal chariot being harnessed, Basel, Cahn 802, which is attributed to Exekias (Mackay, Tradition and Originality; a study of Exekias, pl. 82; Beazley Archive 30292).
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B600.41)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 465-6, no. B795)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0085) (Phase 1)
